articles.headline: With Software and Soldering, a Non-AT&T iPhone
articles.snippet: A 17-year-old New Jersey resident has published instructions on how to unlock Apple’s iPhone so it will work on some competing cellular networks.
articles.abstract: A 17-year-old New Jersey resident has published instructions on how to unlock Apple’s iPhone so it will work on some competing cellular networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT&T is paying millions to be the exclusive United States provider of Apple’s much-hyped and glowingly reviewed gadget, the iPhone.

articles.headline: To Woo Europeans, McDonald’s Goes Upscale
articles.snippet: The company’s strategy of remodeling its restaurants and tailoring its menu options is paying off in Europe.
articles.abstract: The company’s strategy of remodeling its restaurants and tailoring its menu options is paying off in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Taking a respite from an afternoon of shopping, Ita Clift sips a cappuccino at a McDonald’s. Though she rarely sets foot in the fast-food restaurant, Ms. Clift says she dropped in to this one in the Edgware Road section of Northwest London for a quick boost of energy and because the restaurant “looked so nice and sophisticated.”

articles.headline: Running an Empire? No Sweat
articles.snippet: Despite a tough ride as Time Warner C.E.O., Richard D. Parsons prefers that you never see him busting his chops.
articles.abstract: Despite a tough ride as Time Warner C.E.O., Richard D. Parsons prefers that you never see him busting his chops.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard D. Parsons sat down at a quiet table by a window at Porter House New York, the fine year-old steakhouse on the fourth floor of the Time Warner Building, and looked at his watch. It was 7 p.m. “I’m going to have to leave at 8:30,” he said. “I’ve got another meeting.” He shot me a small, pained shrug. “It’s the middle of August, and I’m still busting my chops.”

articles.headline: Chinese Seek to Buy a U.S. Maker of Disk Drives
articles.snippet: The overture for Seagate Technology has raised concerns among American officials about risks to national security.
articles.abstract: The overture for Seagate Technology has raised concerns among American officials about risks to national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 — A Chinese technology company has expressed interest in buying a maker of computer disk drives in the United States, raising concerns among American government officials about the risks to national security in transferring high technology to China.

articles.headline: Giuliani Boasts of Surplus; Reality Is More Complex
articles.snippet: As mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani left office with a bigger budget deficit than existed when he arrived.
articles.abstract: As mayor of New York, Rudolph W. Giuliani left office with a bigger budget deficit than existed when he arrived.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani has been broadcasting radio advertisements in Iowa and other states far from the city he once led stating that as mayor of New York, he “turned a $2.3 billion deficit into a multibillion dollar surplus.”

articles.headline: With Troop Rise, Iraqi Detainees Soar in Number
articles.snippet: A 50 percent increase in the number of detainees comes, officials said, because U.S. forces are operating in areas where they had not been present for some time.
articles.abstract: A 50 percent increase in the number of detainees comes, officials said, because U.S. forces are operating in areas where they had not been present for some time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 — The number of detainees held by the American-led military forces in Iraq has swelled by 50 percent under the troop increase ordered by President Bush, with the inmate population growing to 24,500 today from 16,000 in February, according to American military officers in Iraq.

articles.headline: If There’s a High-Definition TV in Your Future, Wait Till After the Holidays
articles.snippet: Electronics retailers are selling more HDTVs than ever, but are making less money on them, so they are tightening return policies, dropping entry-level models and pushing additional services.
articles.abstract: Electronics retailers are selling more HDTVs than ever, but are making less money on them, so they are tightening return policies, dropping entry-level models and pushing additional services.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 — Consumers walking into an electronics store looking for a big-screen high-definition TV may find that the place looks and feels different from how it was last Christmas.

articles.headline: Quake Orphan Reflects Peru’s Loss, and Anger
articles.snippet: Relatives of a baby who lost as many as 60 members of his extended family say rescue efforts were tragically slow.
articles.abstract: Relatives of a baby who lost as many as 60 members of his extended family say rescue efforts were tragically slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: PISCO, Peru, Aug. 23 — Through the choking smoke and with little light to guide him, Luis Palomino dug furiously through the rubble of the San Clemente church here two hours after last week’s earthquake buried parishioners under a pile of adobe stones.

articles.headline: Altria Board to Consider a Spinoff Overseas
articles.snippet: The parent company of Philip Morris is considering whether to spin off the international arm of its cigarette business.
articles.abstract: The parent company of Philip Morris is considering whether to spin off the international arm of its cigarette business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The maker of the world’s most popular cigarette, Marlboro, may decide next week that American consumers are too much trouble.

articles.headline: Drop Foreseen in Median Price of U.S. Homes
articles.snippet: Many government officials and housing-industry executives had said that a nationwide decline would never happen.
articles.abstract: Many government officials and housing-industry executives had said that a nationwide decline would never happen.
articles.lead_paragraph: The median price of American homes is expected to fall this year for the first time since federal housing agencies began keeping statistics in 1950.
articles.byline: By David Leonhardt and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Inside the Countrywide Lending Spree
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial systematically led people to high-cost mortgages that were not suited for them, some former employees say.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial systematically led people to high-cost mortgages that were not suited for them, some former employees say.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON its way to becoming the nation’s largest mortgage lender, the Countrywide Financial Corporation encouraged its sales force to court customers over the telephone with a seductive pitch that seldom varied. “I want to be sure you are getting the best loan possible,” the sales representatives would say.

articles.headline: Is There (Middle Class) Life After Maytag?
articles.snippet: The last of the Maytag factories that lifted many people into the middle class in Newton, Iowa, will close in October.
articles.abstract: The last of the Maytag factories that lifted many people into the middle class in Newton, Iowa, will close in October.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa

articles.headline: Why the Roller Coaster Seems Wilder
articles.snippet: In volatile times, investors’ choice of refuge is often the United States Treasury market, which, at $4.4 trillion or so, is easily swamped.
articles.abstract: In volatile times, investors’ choice of refuge is often the United States Treasury market, which, at $4.4 trillion or so, is easily swamped.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKS regained some composure last week, and not a moment too soon for investors worn out by the market’s turbulence. Credit markets remain easily spooked, however, and justifiably so. There is still so much that investors do not know about what lurks in portfolios around the world and exactly when it might jump out and say “boo!”

articles.headline: In 2008 Race, Little Ones Go on the Trail With Daddy
articles.snippet: Five presidential contenders have children under 10, a circumstance historians say has no recent precedent.
articles.abstract: Five presidential contenders have children under 10, a circumstance historians say has no recent precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Emma Claire and Jack Edwards, 9 and 7, were on their umpteenth campaign trip earlier this month, this time through small towns where their father was decrying rural poverty and the power of lobbyists.

articles.headline: Spying Program May Be Tested by Terror Case
articles.snippet: The case of two men convicted of supporting terrorism is central in a push to challenge an eavesdropping program.
articles.abstract: The case of two men convicted of supporting terrorism is central in a push to challenge an eavesdropping program.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBANY, Aug. 22  After a bloody raid by American military forces on an enemy camp in Rawah, Iraq, on June 11, 2003, a Defense Department report took inventory. Eighty suspected terrorists killed. An enormous weapons cache recovered. And, in what the report called “pocket litter,” a notebook with the name and phone number of the imam of a mosque halfway around the world, here in the state capital.

articles.headline: Hear a General, Hug a Sheik: Congress Does the Iraq Circuit
articles.snippet: Roughly 50 lawmakers have been to Iraq this summer, and their impressions are influencing the policy debate.
articles.abstract: Roughly 50 lawmakers have been to Iraq this summer, and their impressions are influencing the policy debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 — On a Sunday morning in early August, just hours after Congress had recessed for the summer, Representative Jan Schakowsky and five of her colleagues boarded a military jet at Andrews Air Force Base. Three flights and a Black Hawk helicopter ride later, they were lunching on asparagus soup and lobster tortellini at the home of Ambassador Ryan C. Crocker in Baghdad.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Damien Cave

articles.headline: As China Roars, Pollution Reaches Deadly Extremes
articles.snippet: China’s pollution problem, like the speed and scale of its rise as an economic power, has shattered all precedents.
articles.abstract: China’s pollution problem, like the speed and scale of its rise as an economic power, has shattered all precedents.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Aug. 25 — No country in history has emerged as a major industrial power without creating a legacy of environmental damage that can take decades and big dollops of public wealth to undo.
articles.byline: By Joseph Kahn and Jim Yardley

articles.headline: ‘South Park’ Creators Win Ad Sharing in Deal
articles.snippet: Comedy Central and the creators of the popular show, “South Park,” have agreed to create a hub to spread the program and related material across the Internet, mobile platforms and video games.
articles.abstract: Comedy Central and the creators of the popular show, “South Park,” have agreed to create a hub to spread the program and related material across the Internet, mobile platforms and video games.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 — In March, the season premiere of “South Park” began by barging into typically risqué territory, with a squirm-inducing bit about the taboo of using a certain racial epithet.

articles.headline: As Counsel, Thompson Walked Capital’s Fine Line
articles.snippet: Fred D. Thompson hopes that his work as an investigator of wrongdoing will help propel him to the presidency.
articles.abstract: Fred D. Thompson hopes that his work as an investigator of wrongdoing will help propel him to the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Reagan administration was only a few months old when it faced a major test: Senators were calling for the head of the president’s new director of central intelligence, and no one knew if he would survive their investigation into his tangled past business dealings and questionable agency management.

articles.headline: Your Ad Here, on My S.U.V.? And You’ll Pay?
articles.snippet: Thousands of motorists have agreed to wrap their cars in advertisements in exchange for up to $800 a month.
articles.abstract: Thousands of motorists have agreed to wrap their cars in advertisements in exchange for up to $800 a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some companies pay millions to have their logos on Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s racecar, but others prefer to pay Brian Katz $500 or more a month for space on his Ford Expedition.

articles.headline: Play It Again, Nokia. For the 3rd Time.
articles.snippet: Nokia will revive its most famous misfire, the video game-cellphone hybrid, the N-Gage, as a multiplayer gaming service that will work on its popular line of smartphones.
articles.abstract: Nokia will revive its most famous misfire, the video game-cellphone hybrid, the N-Gage, as a multiplayer gaming service that will work on its popular line of smartphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple had the Newton. Sony struck out with the Betamax. I.B.M. blew it with the PCJr.

articles.headline: Home Depot Unit Sees Price Drop in Tight Market
articles.snippet: The company dropped the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion, one of the first big buyouts renegotiated amid the credit squeeze.
articles.abstract: The company dropped the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion, one of the first big buyouts renegotiated amid the credit squeeze.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home Depot was forced to drop the sale price of its commercial supply business by nearly $2 billion yesterday, according to people involved in the negotiations, one of the first big buyouts to be renegotiated as a result of the recent tightening of credit and problems in the housing market.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: ‘To Catch a Predator’ Is Falling Prey to Advertisers’ Sensibilities
articles.snippet: The high ratings for the program have come at a high price for NBC, as some advertisers say they are wary of being associated with the show’s content.
articles.abstract: The high ratings for the program have come at a high price for NBC, as some advertisers say they are wary of being associated with the show’s content.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last 18 months, NBC’s investigative segment “To Catch a Predator” has received wide attention, rejuvenating ratings for the network’s “Dateline NBC” newsmagazine and making a celebrity of Chris Hansen, the show’s host, who confronts men trolling online chat rooms hoping to meet teenagers for sex.

articles.headline: Bank Profits May Well Suffer, but Credit Crisis Hardly Leaves Them Defenseless
articles.snippet: No one knows how large the earnings losses at banks will be, but the turmoil in the credit markets will likely hurt the industry over the next couple of financial quarters.
articles.abstract: No one knows how large the earnings losses at banks will be, but the turmoil in the credit markets will likely hurt the industry over the next couple of financial quarters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Banks these days are like football players running the gantlet drill: the turmoil in the credit markets is bound to hit them on one side or the other, even if they make it through.

articles.headline: The Kibbutz Sheds Socialism and Gains Popularity
articles.snippet: Israel’s kibbutzim are once again thriving, attracting new members with a mellower version of collective living.
articles.abstract: Israel’s kibbutzim are once again thriving, attracting new members with a mellower version of collective living.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIBBUTZ YASUR, Israel — For much of Israel’s existence, the kibbutz embodied its highest ideals: collective labor, love of the land and a no-frills egalitarianism.
